parts.text:
The FOI document LEX7939 directly substantiates left-leaning concerns regarding the "designated elector" scheme, particularly its alarming implications for social equity and democratic accountability. The data reveals a concerning surge in disenfranchisement, with 211 individuals declared "designated electors" in the 2024/25 financial year, a dramatic increase from single digits or 37 in previous periods. This sharp rise directly undermines the principle of universal suffrage by actively contracting democratic inclusion for vulnerable populations deemed mentally incapacitated.

Crucially, the document highlights that all these declarations were made by "delegates" of the Electoral Commissioner, reinforcing serious questions about the lack of robust oversight by high-level officials and the delegation of immense power without commensurate accountability. The avenues for review or reinstatement are shown to be extremely limited and ineffective: only a handful of internal review applications were made (e.g., 4 in 2024/25), and nearly all these decisions were confirmed, effectively leading to permanent disenfranchisement. The complete absence of applications for review to the Administrative Review Tribunal and the zero declarations ceasing to have effect further underscore the severe lack of accessible and effective recourse, highlighting a system that fails to uphold fundamental voting rights and lacks transparency for its dramatic expansion. LEX7939 provides concrete evidence of how this scheme critically deviates from progressive values, eroding core democratic principles and disproportionately impacting the civil liberties of vulnerable citizens.

prompt:
From a left-leaning perspective, summarize this specific document within the context of the FOI request. Emphasize its implications for social equity, environmental concerns, or democratic accountability. The overall FOI overview is: FOI document LEX7939 exposes a concerning "designated elector" scheme that, from a left-leaning perspective, undermines social justice and civil liberties by disenfranchising individuals deemed mentally incapacitated. The alarming surge in these declarations—from single digits to 211 in 2024/25—raises serious questions about the contraction of democratic inclusion for vulnerable populations, challenging the principle of universal suffrage. Further concerns stem from the process's lack of robust oversight by high-level officials and the extremely limited avenues for review or reinstatement, effectively leading to permanent disenfranchisement. This system critically deviates from progressive values by eroding fundamental voting rights and lacking transparency and accountability for its dramatic expansion.

Document Text:

LEX7939  

FOI Request LEX7939 – Designated Electors Data  

I seek access to the following, as at the close of rolls 7 April 2025: 

1. The number of designated electors. 

1a. Of the number identified in item (1), this number broken down by state or territory. 

1b. Of the numbers identified in items (1) & (1a), this number broken down by electoral division. 

No document response as per decision letter.  

However, the below table extracted from the Australian Electoral Commission (AEC) website sets out 
the number of designated electors per federal electoral event since the introduction of the designated 
elector scheme to the Commonwealth Electoral Act 1918 (i.e. from the 2019 federal election onwards). 
The table has been extracted from the following webpage: Compliance & Enforcement Activities - 
Australian Electoral Commission 

2. The number of designated electors declared in financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 
to date. 

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2022/23: 37  

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2023/24: 1  

Number of designated electors declared in financial year 2024/25: 211  

2a. Of the numbers identified in item (2), a breakdown of whether the declaration was made by 
the Electoral Commissioner or a delegate. 

Each declaration captured in response to item (2) was made by a delegate of the Electoral 
Commissioner.  

Australian Electoral Commission  

www.aec.gov.au 

 
 
 
 
 
 
 3. The number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in 
financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 to date. 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2022/23: 4 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2023/24: 0 

Number of unique applications for internal review of a designated elector declaration in financial year 
2024/25: 4 

4. The outcome of unique internal review decisions (i.e. confirmed or set aside) of declared 
designated electors review applications made in financial years 2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 
to date. 

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2022/23: 4 confirmed  

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2023/24: N/A 

Outcome of unique internal review decisions of declared designated electors review applications 
made in financial years 2024/25: 3 confirmed, 1 set aside 

4. The number of unique applications for review to the Administrative Review Tribunal of a 
declared designated elector in financial year 2024/25 to date. (I have assumed the 
Commission is notified) 

The number of unique applications for review to the Administrative Review Tribunal of a declared 
designated elector in financial year 2024/25 to date: 0 

5. The number of declarations ceasing to have effect by virtue of s 202AH(3) in financial years 
2022/23, 2023/24 and 2024/25 to date. 

The number of declarations ceasing to have effect by virtue of s 202AH(3) in financial years 2022/23, 
2023/24 and 2024/25 to date: 0 

Australian Electoral Commission  

www.aec.gov.au 

 
 
 
 
 
 

Provide only the markdown formatted summary text. Do not include any conversational filler or preamble.
